rows.text: Project Name, Project Number, Subcontractor Name, Subcontract Number

List personnel who developed the JSA.
Enter Subcontractor employee name
Enter names of individuals and their S number, on Page 2, that provided input to hazards identification and hazards control portion of the JSA and/or who have read and understand the contents of the JSA.

Personnel working to the JSA shall be briefed by a subcontractor representative. Briefed personnel must give concurrence for the contents of the JSA by providing their S number, printed name, signature and date of briefing.
Personnel working to the JSA shall be briefed of any changes made to the JSA and give concurrence of the changes.
Specifically identify facility building and/or area where work will occur.

All revisions must be initialed, dated and reviewed by original reviewers and personnel retrained prior to start of work. All reviewers shall only review the latest revised content for acceptance or to provide comments.
Enter the revision number and date with an associated highlight color to reference the content changed or added to the JSA.
REVIEWED BY POC and S&H REPRESENTATIVE:

Signature indicates by whom the JSA was reviewed and accepted as an adequate analysis of the job.
INL POC shall review and sign for subcontract work. POC will Initiate and obtain SME signatures, if required. The INL Safety and Health Representatives shall review and sign for subcontract work.

The signature and date indicate approval by the authorized subcontractor representative.
The Subcontractor Project Manager, Superintendent, technician, lead or representative shall review and sign approval for subcontract work.
BRIEFLY DESCRIBE THE JOB AND EXPECTED RESULT:
Give a summary description of the activity and its purpose.

Describe the job in detail, step by step, from beginning to end. (Before examining the job for potential hazards, define the job as a series of tasks or steps. Use judgment to avoid either excessive or insufficient detail. Each step should begin with an action, such as lift, place, remove, position, install, etc.) Verify the recorded steps with the performer to ensure completeness and accuracy.

List the hazards associated with each step. (To ensure that all hazards associated with a step are identified, examine hazards produced by both work environment and the activity being performed. For guidance, as a minimum, consider the following: * Is there a danger of striking against, being struck by, or otherwise making harmful contact with an object? * Can the worker be caught in, by, or between objects? * Is there potential for a slip or trip? * Can the employee fall from one level to another or even on the same level? * Can pushing, pulling, lifting, bending, or twisting cause strain? * Is the environment hazardous to safety or health? * Are there concentrations of toxic gas, vapor, fumes, or dust? * Are there potential exposures to heat, cold, noise, or ionizing radiation? * Are there flammable, explosive, or electrical hazards?)
Be specific when listing the hazards to personnel.

List the methods to control the identified hazards. (Engineering or administrative controls to isolate workers from hazards are preferred over the use of PPE. For guidance, as a minimum, consider the following: * Find a new way to do the job. * Change the physical conditions that create the hazard. * Revise the work procedure or process. * Reduce the frequency of the job. * Enhance training before performing the job. * Increase monitoring or supervision during the job. * Implement administrative controls when the hazard cannot be eliminated by engineering controls. * Prescribe specific PPE when appropriate.
List any required/specialty training courses, qualifications, or certifications where applicable. List each potential hazard and the mitigation for each hazard.
Note: Recognize the potential for creating additional hazards when modifying the initial process.
Subcontractors Requirements Manual, RD-1003, “General Information and Requirements.”

1. A. Heavy machinery 
(I.E. struck by, and noise)

1.A1 Stay out of pinch points, swing radius, and working areas of equipment. 

1.A2 Workers wear high visibility vests. 

1.A3 Ensure Backup alarms are operational and utilized when reversing. 

1.A4 Monitor sound levels and establish a sound perimeter in accordance with readings.

1.A5 If sound levels reach 84 dba, wear hearing protection. If sound levels reach 100 dba double hearing protection is required.

1.B1 Utilize proper lifting techniques (ex. Do not lift with back) 

1.B2 Do not lift items over 50lbs or 1/3 of body weight (whichever is less). Team lift items that are heavier. 

1.B3 Wherever possible, use mechanical means to lift. 

1.B4 Ensure that workers are made aware of potential pinch points and the potential hazards prior to starting the task. 

1.B5 Position out of potential pinch points during equipment operation, and where possible use tools or machinery to interact with pinch points.

2.A1 Construction area will be barricaded and properly posted. 

2.A2 Ensure that the excavation checklist has been filled out by a competent person.

2.A3 Ensure a subsurface investigation is performed. Obtain and review the results, then implement requirements identified 

2.A4 All affected employees shall be informed of the SI results during the daily pre-job briefing.
3.A Bodily injury, eye injury, face injury and noise.

3.A1 Prior to work, ensure whip lines are in place on all air hoses and inspect equipment prior to use ensuring that all air lines are in good working order. 

3.A2 Check equipment for safety and functionality. Ensure all guards are in place. 

3.A3 Wear full face shields while operating water and air pick. When in proximity to operator wear a face shield. 

3.A4 Monitor sound levels. Establish sound perimeter in accordance with readings.

3.A5 If sound levels reach 84 dba, wear hearing protection. If sound levels reach 100 dba double hearing protection is required.  

3.A6 Wear sturdy leather boots, leather gloves, and hard hat.
4.A1 Position out of potential pinch points during equipment operation, and where possible use tools or machinery to interact with pinch points.
4.B Burn from contact, incipient fire, Fuel Spills

4.B1 No open flames or smoking during refueling. 

4.B2 Avoid spills. In the event of a spill notify the CFR immediately. If the CFR is unavailable contact the spill notification team.

4.B3 Keep spill control equipment available on site. 

4.B4 Maintain a fire extinguisher on site and ensure everyone knows where it is located.
4.C Heavy machinery accident, roll over (bodily injury)

4.C1 Ensure equipment is equipped with proper roll over protection. 

4.C2 Wear seatbelt at all times. 

4.C3 Follow the equipment’s operator’s manual. 

4.C4 Make sure workers on the ground stay out of equipment’s possible roll over path. .

4.D1 Drivers must obey all traffic laws state and federal traffic laws. 

4.D2 Wear seat belts. 

4.D3 Where necessary place proper traffic control signs on local roadways.
4.E Damage to existing utilities possible shock, overhead hazards (power lines) and other obstacles.

4.E1 Ensure a subsurface investigation is performed, and that the excavation checklist has been filled out by a competent person.

4.E3 A spotter is to be utilized when the operator is unable to see or is operating within 10’ of an object. 

4.E4 Ensure SI marked interferences are located by hand dig or soft dig techniques. This shall be done to 1 ft below the depth of the planned excavation and 5 ft in each perpendicular direction to attempt to locate the utility.

4.E5 Mechanical excavating will only be allowed if the distance of 2 ft vertically and 5 ft horizontally is maintained from all verified utilities.

4.F1 Excavation checklist to be completed prior to excavation. 

4.F2 Keep equipment and excavated materials at least 2’ away from the edge of excavation. 

4.F3 If excavation is 5’ in depth or greater 1.5 to 1 slope or trench box is required or do not enter the excavation. 

4.F4 For ingress and egress of excavations over 4’ deep a ladder(s) will be provided at intervals of 50’ or less. Or the trench will be sloped at 1.5’ to 1’. 

4.F5 Excavations that are not sloped will require signage and candles with rope to warn of hazards, restrict access, and keep people at a safe distance from open excavations.

4.G1 Keep work area clean of unnecessary materials and debris.

4.G2 Utilize equipment manufacturers steps, ladders, and handrails for entering and exiting equipment. 

4.G3 Ensure equipment steps, ladders, and handrails for entering and exiting equipment have no damage prior to use. 

4.G4 When entering and exiting equipment maintain three points of contact. 

4.G5 Boots worn shall provide traction and provide adequate support to prevent slips, trips, and falls.

4.G6 Excavations that are not sloped will require signage and candles with rope to prevent slips, trips, and falls.

4.H1 Monitor sound levels and establish a sound perimeter in accordance with readings.

4.H2 If sound levels reach 84 dba, wear hearing protection. If sound levels reach 100 dba double hearing protection is required.

4.I1 Prior to lifting material obtain the data and weight of the item being lifted to unsure the capacities of the lifting equipment will not be exceeded. 

4.I2 Utilize a spotter for obstructions near the lift area. 

4.I3 Utilize tag lines. 

4.I4 Prior to lift inspect the rigging. 

4.I5 Never place personal under a load.

4.J1 Ensure hazard assessments are completed during hot and cold weather conditions. 

4.J2 Participate in the hazard assessment process. 

4.J4 Follow the recommended schedule of rest breaks, as advised by supervisors, to prevent heat or cold stress injuries. 

4.J5 Follow road closure information from Idaho DOT.

4.J6 Monitor weather via NOAA website.

4.K1 Ensure there is adequate water kept on site and stay hydrated. 

4.K2 Ensure that an adequate amount and frequency of breaks is taken to cool down and avoid heat stress. 

4.K3 Use the buddy system to check on fellow co-workers. 

4.K4 Wear proper clothing for heat and other jobsite conditions. (loose fitting cotton clothes are best for summer). 

4.K5 Inform the superintendent of any physical conditions that could be worsened by heat.

4.L1 Temperatures below 0 degrees F will require special attention and a briefing in the pre-job ensuring that personnel have the necessary clothing, boots, gloves, hats, or beanies.

4.L2 Warming areas will be available to personnel as needed. 

4.L3 Use the buddy system to check on fellow co-workers.

4.L4 Inform the superintendent of any physical conditions that could be worsened by cold temperatures.

4.M1 Use water to control dust plumes when breaking or cutting asphalt and concrete. 

4.M2 Ensure others in the area are not in a visible dust plume. 

4.M3 Follow manufactures requirements for equipment used to cut or break asphalt and concrete. 

4.M4 Operators should remain in the cab with doors and windows closed. 

4.M5 Wear a face shield while saw cutting.
5. Hand Power Tools and Handling and removing of Materials

5.A1 Prior to use, inspect cords and tools for damage and wear. Do not use the item, and remove it from service, if any damage is found. 

5.A2 Use a ground fault protector.

5.B1 Monitor sound levels and establish a sound perimeter in accordance with readings. 

5.B2 If sound levels reach 84 dba, wear hearing protection. If sound levels reach 100 dba double hearing protection is required.
5.C1 Wear leather gloves, pants, sturdy work boots, hard hat, and safety glasses.

5.D1 Utilize proper lifting techniques (ex. Do not lift with back) 

5.D2 Do not lift items over 50lbs or 1/3 of body weight (whichever is less). Team lift items that are heavier. 

5.D3 Wherever possible, use mechanical means to lift.

5.D4 Ensure that workers are made aware of potential pinch points and the potential hazards prior to starting the task. 

5.D5 Position out of potential pinch points during equipment operation, and where possible use tools or machinery to interact with pinch points.

5.E1 Wear safety glasses with side shields. 

5.E2 As needed use a face shield. 

5.E3 Wear a face shield while saw cutting.
6. Use LASER to shoot grade and establish elevations
6. A Laser work possible eye injury.

6.A1 Notify IH of laser class and power. 

6.A2 Do not allow eyes to come in direct contact of the laser beam. 

6.A3 Set the laser above or below eye level. 

6.A4 Ensure personnel have proper training prior to operating a laser.
7.A1 Excavations may require radiological coverage and monitoring.

8.A1 Wear metatarsal cap foot protection. 

8.A1 Wear hearing protection. 

8.A3 Prior to performing work, check equipment for safety and functionality.

8.B1 Utilize proper lifting techniques (ex. Do not lift with back

8.B2 Do not lift items over 50lbs or 1/3 of body weight (whichever is less). Team lift items that are heavier. 

8.B3 Wherever possible, use mechanical means to lift.

8.B4 Ensure that workers are made aware of potential pinch points and the potential hazards prior to starting the task.
